2 Poems

manuel arturo abreu

untitled 1 </br></br>

A room with</br> windows. A</br> room without.</br></br>

Repeat it</br> out loud. Stare</br> at it on paper.</br></br>

Different</br> meanings</br> are lost.</br></br>

Different</br> kinds of</br> light.</br></br></br>

untitled 2</br></br>

I refuse to become</br> what I am since</br></br>

a key is</br> not a balloon.</br></br>

Phrases keep</br> flickering through</br></br>

me aloft on their</br> hunger like stomachs.</br></br>

& how could a word</br> not go barefoot?</br></br>

–I am always refusing</br> to mean.</br></br>

*</br></br>

Daylight’s engine</br> has turned me,</br></br>

spry on my</br> pivoting ache.</br></br>

I hate it when</br> morning is goading:</br></br>

my heart has no</br> hinges at night.</br></br>

The moon never</br> argued when I’d</br></br>

build a full trellis</br> of moans.
